Definitions

Published

May 28, 2023

Main functions

We overall interact with two functions, \(\ell\) and \(g\), which are defined as

\[\ell(t)\triangleq -\alpha t + \beta\qquad\text{for some}\;\alpha,\beta > 0\]

and

\[g(t)\triangleq \eta\exp\left( \;-\sigma \; t\;\right)\qquad\text{for some}\; \eta, \sigma > 0\]

these functions serve as a proxy to define a third function, called ‚Äúswitch‚Äù or \(\mathrm{S}_\boldsymbol{\theta}\), which is defined as

\[\mathrm{S}_\boldsymbol{\theta}(t) = \begin{cases} \ell_\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)&\text{if}\;t\leq t_s\\ g_\boldsymbol{\theta}(t) & \text{if}\;t> t_s \end{cases} \]

where \(\boldsymbol{\theta}\) is a vector parameter storing all variables of interest:

\[\boldsymbol{\theta} \triangleq \left(\alpha, \beta, \eta, \sigma, t_s\right)\]

Variables

Variable Description
\(\alpha\) The rate of change of the linear function
\(\beta\) The initial value of the linear function
\(\eta\) The amplitude of the exponential function
\(\sigma\) The rate of decay of the exponential function
\(t_s\) The time at which the switch function changes from linear to exponential

Relationships between the variables

From the continuity assumption, we get

\[\ell(t_s) = g(t_s)\]

and

\[\ell'(t_s) = g'(t_s)\]

which provides for the equations

\[-\alpha t_s+ \beta = \eta \exp(-\sigma\cdot t_s)\] and \[\alpha = \sigma\eta\exp(-\sigma\cdot t_s)\]

Derivation of key quantities

To avoid the occasionnal handwriting mistake, we can symbollically solve the arithmetic using symbolic programming:

Substitutions

Code 
from sympy import *

Œ±, Œ≤, œÉ, Œ∑ = symbols('Œ± Œ≤ œÉ Œ∑', positive=True)

t_s, T_L, T_0 = symbols('t_s T_L T_0', positive=True)


eqns = [
    -Œ± * t_s+ Œ≤ - Œ∑ * exp(- œÉ * t_s),
    Œ± - œÉ * Œ∑ * exp(-œÉ * t_s),
]
init_printing()
sols = solve(eqns, [t_s]).pop()
sols[0]

\(\displaystyle \log{\left(\left(\frac{Œ∑ œÉ}{Œ±}\right)^{\frac{1}{œÉ}} \right)}\)

Whence from substitution we get

\[-\alpha t_s + \beta = \eta \exp\left(-\sigma\log\left(\left(\dfrac{\eta\sigma}{\alpha}\right)^{1/\sigma}\right)\right) = \eta \dfrac{\alpha}{\eta\sigma}\]

which implies

\[t_s = \dfrac{\beta}{\alpha} - \dfrac1\sigma = \beta\alpha^{-1} - \sigma^{-1}\]

Integration

We can even solve the intergral symbollically to avoid silly mistakes

Code 
t = symbols('t')

conds = [
    (t_s > T_0, True), (t_s < T_L, True),
    (T_0 < T_L, True), (t < T_L, True),
    (t > T_0, True)
]

lS = Piecewise((-Œ±*t+Œ≤, True), *conds)
rS = Piecewise((Œ∑ * exp(-œÉ * t), True), *conds)
total = lS.integrate((t,T_0, t_s)).doit() + rS.integrate((t, t_s, T_L)).doit()
expand(expand_log(powsimp(total.subs(t_s, Œ≤/Œ±- 1/œÉ))))

\(\displaystyle \frac{T_{0}^{2} Œ±}{2} - T_{0} Œ≤ - \frac{Œ±}{2 œÉ^{2}} + \frac{e Œ∑ e^{- \frac{Œ≤ œÉ}{Œ±}}}{œÉ} - \frac{Œ∑ e^{- T_{L} œÉ}}{œÉ} + \frac{Œ≤^{2}}{2 Œ±}\)

Whence the integral we care about

\[\int_{T_0}^{T_\text{L}}\mathrm{S}_\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)\mathrm{d}t \leq \mathrm{B} \iff \int_{T_0}^{t_s}\ell_\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)\mathrm{d}t + \int_{t_s}^{T_\text{L}}g_\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)\mathrm{d}t \leq \mathrm{B}\]

A final simplification is \[\alpha = \sigma\eta\exp(-\sigma\beta\alpha^{-1} + \sigma\sigma^{-1} ) = \sigma\eta\exp(1- \sigma\beta\alpha^{-1} ) \]

Our final expression for the cost is

\[ \displaystyle \frac{T_{0}^{2} Œ±}{2} - T_{0} Œ≤ - \frac{Œ±}{2 œÉ^{2}} + \frac{\alpha }{œÉ^2} - \frac{Œ∑ e^{- T_{L} œÉ}}{œÉ} + \frac{Œ≤^{2}}{2 Œ±} \]

Derivatives

What might be of important in scenario is that the acceleration shouldn‚Äôt be too steep. That means spread the effort enough that we do not need to ‚Äúaccelerate‚Äù too suddenly. This means the \(\mathrm{L}_2\) norm of the acceletation wrt \(t\) of \(\mathrm{S}_\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)\) should be low.

\[\displaystyle\int_{T_0}^{T_\text{L}}\left|\dfrac{\partial}{\partial t^2}\mathrm{S}_\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)\right|^2\mathrm{d}t = \left\lVert\dfrac{\partial}{\partial t^2}\mathrm{S}_\boldsymbol{\theta}\right\rVert \ll K \qquad\text{for some }\; K > 0\]

Since the linear function has curvature zero, we only care about the \(t > t_s\) case

\[\dfrac{\partial}{\partial t^2} \eta\exp(-\sigma\cdot t) = \eta\sigma^2\exp(-\sigma\cdot t)\]

finally,

\[ \begin{aligned} \left\lVert\dfrac{\partial}{\partial t^2}\mathrm{S}_\boldsymbol{\theta}\right\rVert &= \eta^2\sigma^4\displaystyle\int_{t_s}^{T_\text{L}}\exp(-2\sigma\cdot t)\,\mathrm{d}t \\ & = -\dfrac12\sigma^{-1}\eta^2\sigma^4\left[\exp(-2\sigma T_\text{L}) - \exp(-2\sigma t_s)\right]\\ & = -\dfrac12\sigma^{-1}\eta^2\sigma^4\left[\exp(-2\sigma T_\text{L}) - \dfrac{\alpha^2}{\eta^2\sigma^2}\right] \\ &= -\dfrac12\sigma^{-1}\eta^2\sigma^4\exp(-2\sigma T_\text{L}) + \dfrac12 \eta^2\sigma\alpha^2 \end{aligned} \]

Relationships

Number Variables Expression
1 \(t_s\) \(-\frac{1}{\sigma}\ln\left(\frac{\alpha}{\eta\sigma}\right)\)
2 \(\exp(-\sigma \cdot t_s)\) \(\dfrac{\alpha}{\eta\sigma}\)
3 \(t_s\) \(\dfrac{\eta}{\sigma}\exp(-\sigma \cdot t_s)\)
4 \(\displaystyle\int_{T_0}^{T_\text{L}}\mathrm{S}_\boldsymbol{\theta}(t)\mathrm{d}t\) \(\frac{T_{0}^{2} Œ±}{2} - T_{0} Œ≤ - \frac{Œ±}{2 œÉ^{2}} + \frac{\alpha }{œÉ^2} - \frac{Œ∑ e^{- T_{L} œÉ}}{œÉ} + \frac{Œ≤^{2}}{2 Œ±}\)
5 \(\left\lVert\dfrac{\partial}{\partial t^2}\mathrm{S}_\boldsymbol{\theta}\right\rVert\) \(-\dfrac12\sigma^{-1}\eta^2\sigma^4\exp(-2\sigma T_\text{L}) + \dfrac12 \eta^2\sigma\alpha^2\)
